title: Quiz 10: Wound Care, Respiratory & Immunisation
topicName: Essential Knowledge and Skills for Healthcare Assistants
description: Assess skills in wound management, respiratory testing, and vaccine administration.

questions.question: Order the phases of wound healing:
questions.explanation: Stop bleeding -> Inflammation -> New tissue -> Strengthening scar.
questions.hint: Stop blood, clean up, rebuild, strengthen.

questions.question: A low FEV1/FVC ratio in spirometry usually indicates ___BLANK___ airways disease (e.g., COPD).
questions.explanation: Obstructive disease (like COPD) makes it hard to get air OUT quickly, lowering the ratio.

questions.question: What is the correct angle for an Intramuscular (IM) injection?
questions.explanation: IM injections go straight in at 90 degrees.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical signs of wound infection? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Pain, redness, heat, swelling, and smell are signs of infection. Pink granulation is healthy healing.
questions.hint: Signs of inflammation/infection vs healthy healing.

questions.question: Live vaccines (like Shingles Zostavax) should generally be avoided in pregnant women and immunocompromised patients.
questions.explanation: Live vaccines can potentially cause the disease in those with weak immune systems or affect the fetus.
questions.hint: Can a live virus harm a weak immune system?

questions.question: Match the wound dressing type with its function:

pairs.right: Maintains moist environment, good for granulating wounds
Highly absorbent, good for bleeding/exuding wounds
Transparent protection for low exudate wounds

questions.explanation: Hydrocolloids hydrate; Alginates absorb; Silver kills bacteria; Films protect.

questions.question: What is the recommended temperature range for storing vaccines (the 'Cold Chain')?
questions.explanation: 2-8 degrees Celsius is the safe range.

questions.question: When performing ear irrigation, where should the water jet be directed?

options.text: Towards the roof of the ear canal (posterior wall)
Towards the floor of the ear canal

questions.explanation: Direct towards the posterior wall (back of head) to avoid direct pressure on the drum and create a vortex to flush wax out.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the 'Aseptic Non-Touch Technique' (ANTT)?

options.text: To prevent introduction of pathogens to key sites

questions.explanation: ANTT is designed to prevent infection by protecting 'key parts' and 'key sites' from contamination.

questions.question: What is a 'Patient Specific Direction' (PSD)?

options.text: A verbal order from a doctor
A written instruction signed by a prescriber for a specific patient to receive a medicine
A general policy for the clinic
A leaflet given to the patient

questions.explanation: A PSD is the legal written authorization required for a HCA to administer a prescription-only medicine/vaccine.
questions.hint: It is Specific to the Patient.
